Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Story:
I stood behind the register, the hum of the store blending with the anxious thoughts swirling in my head. My mentor’s message echoed in my mind: “Finish the code sample before our next meeting.” I had three days, but my shifts as a cashier left me little time. As I rang up a customer, another approached, holding a blender and looking frustrated. “I need to return this, but I lost the receipt,” she said. I knew the store’s policy—no returns without proof of purchase. My manager expected me to enforce it strictly, but the customer’s pleading eyes made me hesitate.

At the same time, my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder to review the code sample. I felt the weight of my mentor’s trust and the pressure to prove myself. But here, in this moment, I was the cashier, expected to uphold the rules. My mind raced, torn between the demands of my mentor and my job. I could feel the stress building, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
